Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dendritic Processing of Topographic Information in a Collision Detecting Neuron
Award.AbstractNarration:
The brain regions devoted to the processing of sensory information are remarkable for their two-dimensional map-like (topographic) organization. Recent evidence suggests that this property can be maintained down to the subcellular level, in the form of topographically organized inputs onto the extended arborizations (dendrites) of single cells (neurons). The goal of this project is to identify the key principles underlying the processing of such topographic inputs in the dendrites of a prototypical neuron. The project focuses on a nerve cell that is most sensitive to objects approaching on a collision course with the animal and that is implicated in generating collision avoidance behaviors. The investigators use tools developed to study partial differential equations to determine the detailed dendritic distribution of the cell's ion channels. Next, techniques designed to reduce the complexity of mathematical models are used, as well as to simultaneously respect the topography of inputs, to extract a simplified representation of the neuron?s signal processing characteristics. This allows the investigators to characterize the role played by the neuron's dendrites in generating the responses of the neuron to objects approaching on a collision course. Particular focus is on understanding the invariance of responses to objects approaching from different directions.

The survival of all animals, including humans, critically depends on the neuronal processing of impending dangers. This project sheds light on how the brain accomplishes this feat in a particular model system ideally suited for this purpose. Mathematical tools are generated and are made available to other researchers to analyze neurons with similar properties in other contexts. Additionally, the project contributes to our basic understanding of brain function that may eventually lead to better cures for diseases affecting sensory perception. Finally, the results of this project could potentially find applications in the design of autonomous robots.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated how neural information is processed within the dendritic tree of a neuron located in the visual system of locusts that detects and tracks objects approaching on a collision course with the animal. Its role is to trigger collision avoidance behaviors in the face of an impending, life-threatening danger. One important characteristic of this neuron is that it receives visual information that is organized in a topographic manner, that is, nearby locations in visual space are mapped to nearby locations in the dendrites of the neuron. We developed experimental techniques allowing us to study this retinotopy with high spatial resolution and found that it is highly precise. In addition, we found that nearby regions in visual space activate overlapping localized regions of the dendrites. In parallel, we developed mathematical tools to simulate the visual inputs received by the neuron during the approach of an object, both in a simplified manner and in a highly realistic manner. These tools were used to sharpen our conceptual understanding of how the neuron processes visual information about impending collision. Using these mathematical methods and further experimental techniques to inactivate specific ion channels in the dendritic membrane of the neuron, we found that retinotopy is critical for the neuron to distinguish between a true object approaching on a collision course and a spatially incoherent random version of it. Using our mathematical methods, we were able to explain how this neural computation is carried out within the dendrites of the neuron. Our experimental and mathematical results illustrate how a single neuron can carry out a computation akin to visual object segmentation that is critical to implement appropriate collision avoidance behaviors. These findings have implication for the design of artificial collision avoidance systems and for our understanding of how retinotopy and dendritic ion channels contribute to neuronal information processing in other animals.
